text: Won’t feel particularly revelatory to anyone who has frequented the spy-centric cinematic well enough to have a familiarity with every trope from Bond to Bourne, but Burger’s staging is what allows Inheritance to succeed beyond the trappings.
Inheritance essentially rests on how engaging Dynevor is in the context of this very labyrinthian story
She never becomes Jason Bourne... She's figuring it out, and we're figuring it out right alongside her.
Inheritance is a dynamic thriller with plenty action sequences, some unexpected twists and turns, and solid acting.
With Dynevor, Ifans, and a few effective twists and surprises, Inheritance makes for a mildly entertaining espionage thriller.
Better as a travelogue than as a movie.
Dodging restrictions and permits, there’s almost an anxiety in the filmmaking which feeds the tension in its story. Then there’s the sheer visual craftsmanship which impresses on many levels.
The solid performances, in particular Phoebe Dynevor's pout-y charisma, make “Inheritance” a modest yet entertaining espionage yarn.
Inheritance is too coherent and competent to be described as a truly bad movie, yet it’s far from the territory of a good one.
The gimmicky film was shot guerilla style entirely on an IPhone.
The minimalist plot makes this a standard-issue spy thriller, but Phoebe Dynevor and Rhys Ifans are convincing and focused. I was fully engaged. A tense thrill ride with first-rate performances.

Inheritance shines through its impromptu filming style and the strength of its lead performances. Neil Burger pushes the boundaries of traditional filmmaking, proving that creativity and technical skill can overcome any financial limitations.
If you’re looking for a spy film with the right amount of thrill but without too much intellectual fanfare, then Inheritance might be for you.
It is ultimately a shallow, anti-climactic affair that uses espionage to thinly disguise a predictable daughter confronting her disillusionment with her dad.
“Inheritance” is a throwback thriller that harkens to the retro days of the Y2K era. And while its style eclipses its substance, it’s the style that makes this cinematic curio worth watching.

Burger smartly exploits the freedom of shooting with an iPhone13 in streets, markets, planes and trains. He makes exotic countries his special effects, their people his extras. It's conceptually brilliant. Dynevor's Maya is a believable badass rebel.
The scope of travel, Phoebe's performance, and the questions the movie presents keep Inheritance interesting even with the spatters of drag, but little stands out.
Inheritance moves at a breakneck pace, capturing a world of paranoia at literal face value.
If only it were as interesting to watch Inheritance as it is to read about it.
Not only does “Inheritance” fail to sell its aesthetic; it doesn’t sell its story, either.
